description: Alteration of older garsh, from Middle English garsen, from Old French garser, jarsier (Modern French gercer), from Vulgar Latin *charaxāre, from Ancient Greek χαρακτήρ (kharaktḗr, “engraver”).

adjectives.description: gash (comparative more gash, superlative most gash)

entries.meaning: (slang) Of poor quality; makeshift; improvised; temporary; substituted.

examples: Vowing that he was “never going to forget the lessons of that day,” President Bush paid tribute last night to the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack, laying wreaths at ground zero, attending a prayer service at St. Paul’s Chapel and making a surprise stop at a firehouse and a memorial museum overlooking the vast gash in the ground where the twin towers once stood.
"Will you bastards quit singing the blues? You're young, and there's plenty of gash in the world, and the supply of moon goes on forever," Simonsky said.

entries.meaning: (slang, British Royal Navy) Rubbish, spare kit.
(slang) Unused film or sound during film editing.

verbs.description: gash (third-person singular simple present gashes, present participle gashing, simple past and past participle gashed)

entries.meaning: To make a deep, long cut; to slash.

description: From ghastful, by association with gash.

adjectives.description: gash (comparative more gash, superlative most gash)
